content.question: A circuit contains three identical light bulbs and a switch <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> connected to an ideal battery of <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>emf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="E m f " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Îµ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , as shown in the figure above. The switch is initially open and bulbs <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> have equal brightness, while <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is not lit. What happens to the brightness of bulbs <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when the switch <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is closed and bulb <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> lights up?

choices.label: Bulb ABulb BRemains the sameBecomes dimmer
Bulb ABulb BRemains the sameNot lit

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
